column1: Netflix is advising its employees to be fiscally responsible
column2: while facing a loss of subscribers that has sparked fears about the viability of streaming services.

column1: The employee directive comes in an updated culture memo by the company Thursday. Under the “Judgment” section of the memo
column2: Netflix tells employees to “spend our members’ money wisely” — phrasing that the company used in a 2018 letter to shareholders but has not formalized for staff until now.

column1: This is a marked change from the rest of the largely freewheeling document
column2: which also tells employees to “avoid rules.”

column1: It comes after Netflix reported its first loss of subscribers in a decade. Netflix attributed the 200
column2: 000 subscriber loss to account sharing
column3: the pandemic and increased competition from rivals. Still
column4: the loss at the streaming giant has spooked competitors and investors
column5: who are now questioning whether all streaming services will see a similar slowdown.

column1: In light of the weaker-than-expected subscriber numbers
column2: Netflix said it will explore launching an ad-supported section of the streaming service. Analysts had pointed to the January increase in Netflix’s monthly subscription price for new members in the U.S. and Canada as another reason for the loss of subscribers. The streaming company has also spoken of other cost-cutting measures.

column1: “We’re pulling back on some of our spend growth across both content and non-content spend
column2: ” CFO Spencer Neumann said during the first-quarter earnings call. “We’re trying to be smart about it and prudent in terms of pulling back on some of that spend growth to reflect the realities of the revenue growth of the business.”
as well as executives’ talks of “cutting back” on costs
column3: has caused worry among employees at Netflix
column4: who have seen a slowdown in hiring and fear future layoffs.

column2: Netflix has always stuck by the motto
column4: ” which it reiterated again in Thursday’s updated memo. Variety first reported the details of the memo.

column1: The scene is total chaos: a woman and all her purse's contents in middair as she trips over a child's toy
column2: a man hastily trying to gather his spilled laundry
column3: a screaming child weaving through the crowd. Somewhere
column4: in the midst of it all
column5: is the person you've been looking for: wearing a red and white striped shirt
column6: black rimmed glasses and a lopsided cap. There he is! There's Waldo.

column1: Many of us have fond memories of Waldo. But while he looms large in our imagination
column2: our childhood searches for Waldo typically stayed pretty small – Waldo is a tiny person in the middle of lots of other tiny things.

column1: And that's what this post is about: wee things. Specifically
column2: the wee things that we see as part of graphics
column4: visualizations (wee things in space) as well as the wee things we experience as part of interactions
column6: and usability (wee things in time). This means everything from sequences of small graphics that help us make comparisons
column7: to tiny locator maps that help orient us within a larger graphic
column8: to navigation icons that give hints about how we should make our way around a page.

column2: and the eternal search for him
column3: can actually tell us quite a lot about design. In many ways
column4: Waldo is a great example of what NOT to do when using wee things in your own work. So with Waldo as our anti-hero
column5: let's take a look at how people read and interpret small visual forms
column6: why tiny details can be hugely useful
column7: and what principles we can apply to make all these little images and moments work for us as designers.

column1: Probably the most immediate definition of wee things are things that are physically small: little things on a page. We see these all the time in news graphics
column2: and we're probably familiar with some of their forms: small multiples
column5: etc. I'll go into more details about all of these.

column1: These visual forms work because they serve as extensions of our mind – they are cognitive tools that complement our own mental abilities. They do this by recording information for us to make use of later
column2: lending a hand to our (pretty terrible) working memories
column3: helping us search and discover and recognize. We'll take a look at one task in particular they are great at: letting us make comparisons.

column1: World War II or the Second World War
column2: often abbreviated as WWII or WW2
column3: was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved the vast majority of the world's countries—including all of the great powers—forming two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis powers. In a total war directly involving more than 100 million personnel from more than 30 countries
column4: the major participants threw their entire economic
column6: and scientific capabilities behind the war effort
column7: blurring the distinction between civilian and military resources. Aircraft played a major role in the conflict
column8: enabling the strategic bombing of population centres and the only two uses of nuclear weapons in war. World War II was by far the deadliest conflict in human history; it resulted in 70 to 85 million fatalities
column9: a majority being civilians. Tens of millions of people died due to genocides (including the Holocaust)
column12: and disease. In the wake of the Axis defeat
column14: and war crimes tribunals were conducted against German and Japanese leaders.

column1: The nature of the world has been conceptualized differently in different fields. Some conceptions see the world as unique while others talk of a "plurality of worlds". Some treat the world as one simple object while others analyze the world as a complex made up of many parts. In scientific cosmology the world or universe is commonly defined as "[t]he totality of all space and time; all that is
column2: has been
column3: and will be". Theories of modality
column5: talk of possible worlds as complete and consistent ways how things could have been. Phenomenology
column6: starting from the horizon of co-given objects present in the periphery of every experience
column7: defines the world as the biggest horizon or the "horizon of all horizons". In philosophy of mind
column8: the world is commonly contrasted with the mind as that which is represented by the mind. Theology conceptualizes the world in relation to God
column11: as identical to God or as the two being interdependent. In religions
column12: there is often a tendency to downgrade the material or sensory world in favor of a spiritual world to be sought through religious practice. A comprehensive representation of the world and our place in it
column13: as is commonly found in religions
column14: is known as a worldview. Cosmogony is the field that studies the origin or creation of the world while eschatology refers to the science or doctrine of the last things or of the end of the world.

column2: the term "world" takes a more restricted meaning associated
column4: with the Earth and all life on it
column5: with humanity as a whole or with an international or intercontinental scope. In this sense
column6: world history refers to the history of humanity as a whole or world politics is the discipline of political science studying issues that transcend nations and continents. Other examples include terms such as "world religion"

column1: or computer game is an electronic game that involves interaction with a user interface or input device – such as a joystick
column2: controller
column4: or motion sensing device – to generate visual feedback. This feedback is shown on a video display device
column8: or virtual reality headset. Video games are often augmented with audio feedback delivered through speakers or headphones
column9: and sometimes with other types of feedback
column10: including haptic technology. Computer games are not all video games—for example text adventure games
column12: and so on do not always depend upon a graphics display.

column1: Video games are defined based on their platform
column2: which include arcade video games
column4: and personal computer (PC) games. More recently
column5: the industry has expanded onto mobile gaming through smartphones and tablet computers
column7: and remote cloud gaming. Video games are classified into a wide range of genres based on their type of gameplay and purpose.

column1: The first video game prototypes in the 1950s and 1960s are simple extensions of electronic games using video-like output from large room-size computers. The first consumer video game is the arcade video game Computer Space in 1971. In 1972 came the iconic hit arcade game Pong
column2: and the first home console
column3: the Magnavox Odyssey. The industry grew quickly during the golden age of arcade video games from the late 1970s to early 1980s
column4: but suffered from the crash of the North American video game market in 1983 due to loss of publishing control and saturation of the market. Following the crash
column6: dominated by Japanese companies such as Nintendo
column9: and established practices and methods around the development and distribution of video games to prevent a similar crash in the future
column10: many which continue to be followed. Today
column11: video game development requires numerous skills to bring a game to market

column2: the core industry centered on "AAA" games
column4: experimental games. Coupled with the availability of the Internet and digital distribution
column5: this gave room for independent video game development (or indie games) to gain prominence into the 2010s. Since then
column6: the commercial importance of the video game industry has been increasing. The emerging Asian markets and mobile games on smartphones in particular are altering player demographics towards casual gaming and increasing monetization by incorporating games as a service. As of 2020
column7: the global video game market has estimated annual revenues of US$159 billion across hardware
column9: and services. This is three times the size of the 2019 global music industry and four times that of the 2019 film industry.
